Samantha was bossy; you were submissive. It was for the best that you moved on and found a more perfect match. There were some nights, though, where the pain of loneliness got to you, and you retreated into your worst vice, alcohol, to purge the lingering attachments.

You groaned, expecting to feel the brutal hangover that always followed wild nights, but you were surprisingly clear-headed. Not used to this level of lucidity in the morning, regardless of whether you woke up drunk or not, you continued to lie in bed, waiting for the inevitable grogginess, the early-morning Monday blues. It failed to materialize.

"Wow," you thought. "Maybe today won't be so bad after all."

You turned over to switch off your alarm clock, sensing that you'd woken up earlier than was your custom, and as such making sure the alarm wouldn't go off at 7 AM, when you'd probably be in the shower or kitchen.

Your hand went through where your nightstand should have been.

"Huh?" you said out loud. You pawed at the alarm clock a second time, thinking that maybe you'd missed it, but again, your hand traveled through empty space.

You sat up swiftly, rubbing your eyes before looking over to your right. Where the nightstand once was, there was nothing--only dirty socks on the floor, piled up on top of brightly colored blouses and wrinkled skirts. A few feet past them was a laundry basket, and beyond that, you saw a plain-wood desk with a Macbook Pro, writing utensils, a mess of paper, perfume, a vase of plastic petunias, and stuffed dolls--Beanie Babies, Olaf from Frozen, county-fair prizes, and the sort.

It went without saying that none of these had been in your apartment, so far as you could remember from the previous night.

You looked around you, spotting a cosmetics mirror, a beanbag chair, and a walk-in closet overflowing with female apparel. Behind you, just above the headrest, was a giant One Direction poster, amidst a collage of magazine clippings and male celebrity photos.

"Where the hell am I!" you exclaimed. You rolled out of bed and ran to the window. Lifting the blinds, you saw a residential street flanked by identical houses. There was no city in sight... You'd somehow ended up in the suburbs.

"Inside a teenage girl's bedroom," you added. You'd been pretty drunk last night, but not drunk enough to run out to the suburbs and break into a house you'd never been to.

1411122211.content:
Walking out of the bookstore, you accidentally bump into someone. "Sumimasen..." You mumble.

"Indayo," A female voice replies, but you understand it!

Spinning around, you recognise Akane Nakamura, Ren's older sister. And how can you not recognise her? She's gorgeous, shorter than you and Ren but assertive in family affairs and overprotective of her younger brother. You met her briefly last year along with the rest of Ren's family who live out in the suburbs. She didn't say much, and Ren gave you the impression she couldn't speak English very well (unlike Ren, she spent her formative years in Japan, not your country).

Staring at each other face to face, Akane's confused expression gives way to surprise.

"Dareda? Chotto matte... anata wa Ren no tomodachi?"

You nod excitedly, glad to finally understand someone. "Hai! Boku wa Harold Finnegan desu!"

"Masaka..." She trails off, not believing one of her brother's friends can speak fluent Japanese. She grabs you by the arm and drags you outside, where you sit down at a table.

You explain everything to her, beginning with waking up and hearing gibberish on the radio, then not being able to read the words written on Facebook, to not understanding anything anybody else is saying. You conclude by showing Akane the Japanese language books you purchased from the bookstore while she tries to make sense of it all.

< Yet you say you've never been able to speak Japanese until this morning? > Akane speaks to you in Japanese.

< I can't even think in English right now. It's really freaking me out! > You reply. < I tried calling Ren but he didn't answer. >

Akane nods, < That's because he's on vacation right now. You saw his post on Facebook, right? >

Of course, that was what Ren was talking about in his post to his family. He'll be out of this country for a few weeks, and that means he'll be keeping his cell phone off for the duration to save on roaming charges. In other words, he won't be any help to you.

< Listen Akane. You've got to help me get through this until... whatever condition I have goes away. > You plead.

Akane smiles, < Of course I'll help you Harold. I don't know how this happened, but it'll be nice to speak to someone besides family in my native language. Though... I wonder what caused this to happen? I've heard people under a lot of stress wake up with amnesia and might even speak in another language. But usually they know that language and recall it from memory. >

Briefly you wonder if this effect is stress related. You did just break up with your long-time girlfriend, after all. But if anything you feel relief about moving past that relationship. Not stress. Everything was getting back to normal when this weird change happened.

Akane's lips curved, < Wait a second. Did Ren put you up to this? Oh, I'll get that little brother of mine if this is some kind of elaborate joke! >

Just then, a group of people walk by. A few of them had overheard your conversation with Akane, and while you can't understand their babbling you think it might have something to do with you.

< Okay, Harold. If you really forgot how to speak English, then what did those girls just say about you? > Akane asks.

You gulp. < I have no idea! Besides, if this were a joke what makes you think I would tell you anyway?? >

Akane giggles. < Are you sure you don't want to know what they said about you? >

< Well, when you tease me like this... > You grumble.

Akane folds her arms over her chest. < Okay. I'm convinced you can't speak English. I'm not even that good of a speaker and I know they weren't talking about you at all. Something to do with... what do they call it? That film everyone's talking about? Anyways, judging by your panic you can't be making this up. >

You breathe a sigh of relief. < Now that you believe me, what should I do? I can't go to work like this! > Thankfully it's the weekend, so you don't have to return to your boring office job until Monday. But if this effect holds over until then, you may have to call in sick.

< You can come to Ren's apartment with me for the afternoon. He entrusted me with the keys until he returns from vacation. > Akane takes a set of keys out of her purse and jingles them. < That way you don't have to deal with other tenants in your apartment. Plus, > She winks. < If anyone sees us you can pretend to be my boyfriend! >

Woah! You didn't expect her to say that. She notices you blushing and elbows you playfully.

< I can't believe how fun this is going to be. Come on, let's go! And don't forget your books... sounds like you'll need them! >

Grumbling lowly in Japanese, you grab your books and follow Akane to her car. < So in other words, you're inviting me to stay at your apartment? >

< Don't be cute, > Akane pouts. < This isn't a date. >

< Hey, weren't you going to get something at the bookstore? > You remind her.

Akane simply hand waves it off. < Oh, I was just looking for a birthday gift for a friend back in Osaka. She's always wanted to visit this country and asked me for something special. So I was doing some shopping... but her birthday isn't for another month, so I've got plenty of time. >

Getting into Akane's car, you are amazed at how thorough the change affected your perceptions. Any road signs that have text on them look like gibberish. Bumper stickers are indecipherable, as are the various markings, pamphlets, and user's manuals in her car. What you can understand is one of Akane's J-Pop discs, having popped that into her CD player to listen to her music. Ren's sister can't help but laugh at your frustration.

Finally, she comes to a stop. Where are you two now?

You did the same, grabbing your books and whatnot. Getting out of the car, you thought about just what was going on. Why did such a sudden change happen? It didn't seem natural in the slightest. You didn't really think that stress or anything of the sort was at play. Heck, things were kind of getting better.

14211.content:
You step out into the hallway of your apartment building, still humming a little tune.

It's funny, but for the first time since your recent break-up, you're really feeling good. There's a spring in your step, a smile on your face, and a song on your lip.

Weird, because you never sing! You've never in your life been able to carry a tune. But who cares: you're feeling great, so why hum a catchy little ditty?

In the elevator, you start tapping you toes a bit to the music in your head, even swiveling your hips and pivoting about in a bit of a pantomime dance movement. Mmm you've got rhythm right now, like you've never had before. You're feeling lithe and graceful and incredibly well coordinated. It's as if the music was just flowing through your body, directing your legs and arms to echo back the perfect dance moves to compliment this song.

You don't notice the curious looks from the other people in the elevator until you actually burst out singing aloud again:

“If you liked it, then you should have put a ring on it!” you softly croon, in perfect pitch. “Don't be mad once you see that he want it. If you liked it then you should have put a ring on it! I got gloss on my lips, a man on my hips, got me …”

Then you suddenly snap out of it as the elevator chimes and the doors swing open. The others all snicker a bit at you, but they say nothing as they exit.

Normally, you'd have been pretty embarrassed. But today you just blush a little and then laugh it off with a girly giggle.

“Gawd, I can't believe I was singing in front of all those people,” you whisper to yourself, heading out into the parking lot. Again without being consciously aware of it, there's a rhythmic sway and graceful, dancing bounce to even the simple way you move, navigating through the parking lot. Something about your body language has become delicately artistic, like the controlled professional steps of a trained dancer.

Climbing into your car, you start to pull out of the parking lot when you realize something is wrong. Not with yourself this time, but with the music coming from your stereo speakers! What's this garbage on the radio station this morning? You've always loved this station. Why are they playing such loud, uncouth trash now? Sure, you always listen to classic rock, but today – blech! These songs are horrible. Fiddling with the dial for a moment, you come up with some female artist singing an utterly unfamiliar pop song.

And before you even realize what you're doing, you've pulled out of the parking lot and starting to sing along with this tune you're hearing right now for the very first time!

“The scars of your love remind me of us,” you sing melodically. “They keep me thinking that we almost had it all. The scars of your love, they leave me breathless. I can't help feeling: we could have had it all!”

It's funny.

The breakup with your girlfriend was completely mutual. You agreed it was the best thing, and although you were a little glum about it at first, you welcomed the new freedom you'd enjoy once she moved out of your apartment.

But now, something about the words to this strange woman's song on the radio was really tugging at your heartstrings in a surprisingly effective emotional storm.

You wipe a tear from your eye, still a bit surprised about this sudden flood of maudlin emotions that swept over you. Somehow, you manage to hold back the floodgates of tears until you can pull the car up to a red light and take a moment to compose yourself.

“The raven himself is hoarse that croaks the fatal entrance of Duncan under my battlements,” you whisper to yourself to calm your rattled nerves. You're not sure where these unfamiliar words come from, but suddenly you know them by heart for some reason. “Come, you spirits that tend on mortal thoughts, unsex me here, and fill me from the crown to the toe topful of direst cruelty!”

Weird, you think. That sounds like Shakespeare or something. You've never liked plays or the theater. Why would you suddenly have a passage from some moldy, old play memorized? And why would your mind reach for some weird lines about “unsex me here” to find the calm, steely resolve to soothe your frail, womanly nerves?

Nonetheless, the trick works. You drive off from the intersection feeling much more yourself.

By the time you arrive at work, you're feeling pretty normal, which is a good thing. You're Tech Support at a prestigious law office of computer illiterate nincompoops. The attorneys here all earn ten times what you do, but they can scarcely check their own email without you gracing them with your divinely technical intervention.

And sure enough, they've already got a major SNAFU under way when you arrive.

The receptionist, two of the paralegals, and one of the junior partners at the firm are all clustered around a printer/copier cursing and loudly berating the inanimate lump of plastic and circuitry.

You wish these foolish people would treat the equipment a little more nicely! Half the troubleshooting you do around here is just repairing damage done from impatient, frustrated users who think they can fix computers with their fists!

“Hold on, hold on, let me in to fix it,” you say to the crowd of anxious wage slaves.

“I need these documents printed out ASAP,” growls Mr. Hoskins, the attorney. “You've got to get this blasted machine working now, Finnegan! Without these printouts, I won't be able to nail that miserable bastard to the wall in court today. Oh, and I've got him trapped like a rat too. It's going to be so sweet watching him squirm when he spots the legal technicality I've got him cornered into!”

“Tsk, Tsk, Mr. Hoskins,” you reply with absent minded casualness. You're already on your hands and knees, with your head stuck deep into the mechanical guts of the printer. “The quality of mercy is not strain'd. It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven upon the place beneath. It is twice blest: it blesseth him that gives and him that takes.”

“What the hell are you talking about Finnegan?” roars Hoskins. “I didn't ask for any damned poetry. Just fix the stupid machine, and fix it now!”

This should be an easy, routine repair. This particular model of printer/copier is a lemon. It's always breaking down, and you're always fixing it. Consequently, you've acquired a lot of experience with this specific unit. You can do this type of repair in your sleep!

Unfortunately, now is different.

You can't recall where the network cables go, to connect with the … the … other machines and stuff?

Weird. You can recall all these Shakespeare quotes and crazy song lyrics, but you can't recall how to plug a printer into a computer network?

All these computers and wires and cables and passwords and lines of code – it's dizzying and confusing. You know if you concentrated really hard, you could probably bring these memories back to the surface. But right now, none of your old job skills are flowing naturally to you.

Taking a deep breath, you struggle to remember how to do this very basic part of your job.

And much to your chagrin, the only thing that immediately pops into your head are more song lyrics.

Dammit not right now, you tell yourself.

But there it is: the proverbial song stuck in your head. You can hear the melody, you know the words to this unfamiliar song, and you know you can hit all the high and low notes with perfect pitch if you wanted to.

Once again, almost without realizing you're even doing it, you find yourself bursting into song.

“Whenever I'm alone with you, you make me feel like I am free again,” you sing, the sound echoing pleasantly about the cramped plastic and metal chamber of the printer where you've got your head still crammed into. “Whenever I'm alone with you, you make me feel like I am clean again.”

“I give up!” roars Hoskins.

You can hear him stomping away.

The receptionist and paralegals are softly giggling.

What's happening to you today?

142112.content:
Despite the boss angrily stomping off in irritation at your incompetence, you resolve to stay put and finish the job instead of just making an excuse and going home. Sure, it's true you're not really feeling 100% yourself this morning. But you can hardly justify a sick day on the basis of having some weird, girly songs stuck in your head or suffering a bit of a mental block on how to resolve a tech problem.

Everyone has off days, right?

It takes you about twice as long as normal to revive the dead printer/copier. Your mind feels a bit numb when you try to remember how to perform your usual tech skills, so you essentially wind up re-teaching yourself how to solve this particular problem. Fortunately, you've always been a pretty sharp person. But it's still damned odd that you should draw a complete blank on how to effect repairs.

As you finally complete the repairs, you start walking back to your office again singing a strange little ditty – utterly unfamiliar to you, but now fully implanted in your mind somehow.

“So shine bright, tonight you and I we’re beautiful like diamonds in the sky,” you sing softly, in perfect pitch. “Eye to eye, so alive, we’re beautiful like diamonds in the sky. Shine bright like a diamond!”

From the nearby reception desk, the receptionist and a passing paralegal giggle at you.

“Sorry,” you call out to them, blushing a bit and laughing yourself. “It's a catchy song, though.”

“It's okay, Harry,” says Susan, the receptionist. “I just didn't know you could sing so well.”

“Sorry, sorry!” you laugh again. “I won't spare you any more.”

“No, really,” says Melanie, the paralegal. “We weren't being sarcastic. You've got an amazing voice, Harry. How do you do it, exactly?”

“Do what?” you ask without a clue. “Sing? I just open my mouth and …”

“No, not that,” Susan says. “How do you sing like a woman? You sound normal when you're talking, but every time you start singing your voice like, I don't know, becomes different. It sounds like you're a professional vocalist … only a female one.”

“Really?” you laugh. “That's crazy.”

“Susan is right,” adds Melanie. “When you sing, your voice gets a little higher pitched. But it also sounds way more polished. You could sing professionally, Harry! Though it is a little creepy the way you sound all girly when you sing. You can't sing in a man's voice?”

“I thought I was,” you say. “Let me try again.”

You belt out a few more lines of the same song you'd just been singing.

Susan and Melanie exchange looks of awe and amazement before finally applauding.

“You sound just like a woman when you sing,” says Susan.

“She's right,” Melanie says. “Only you don't just sound like a woman, you sound like a professional female singer. That's a really weird talent you have Harry!”

“I never knew I could do that,” you confess to the girls. Nonetheless, you have to admit they're right. You'd been listening more consciously to yourself this most recent time, and when you started singing it really was the voice of a woman who'd devoted countless hours of practice to honing her musical skills.

“Have you ever thought about being a female impersonator?” Susan asked with a straight face. “No offense, Harry. It's not that I think you're gay or anything. But with that voice, well … you could really fool some people if you got all dressed up in drag and did some singing at a night club or something.”

“That's ridiculous!” you laugh. “I don't want to dress up like a girl and sing at gay bars!”

“No, really!” pressed Susan. “Your singing voice is dead-on for a girl. You should go on stage.”

“Do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe?” you say, again quoting strange theatrical words from some unfamiliar play whose dialogue just mysteriously springs into your head from nowhere. “Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, you cannot play upon me!”

The two girls exchange amused looks at giggle.

“Where's that from?” asks Melanie.

“Hamlet, I think,” you say, a bit surprised that you know the answer to Melanie's question. You've never been interested in theater or acting before. But then again, you've never been able to sing like a female pop star before this morning, either.

“You obviously have a secret flair for the dramatic,” Susan says. “Why have you been hiding this side of yourself, Harry? You really should totally be on stage, singing or acting or something.”

“I'm not going to be a drag queen!” you say again, blushing with embarrassment at the persistent suggestions of the girls.

“You could probably make some pretty good money on the side,” Melanie adds. “Plus, Susan and I could do your hair and makeup, maybe lend you some clothes?”

“No!” you sputter with laughter at the ridiculous suggestion. “I'm not going to start doing drag acts, you two!”

“That's a shame, because you really do have such a pretty voice when you sing,” Susan said seriously. “I'd kill to have your singing voice, Harry. I really think you should reconsider. You have a gift that needs to be shared with the world. You could be amazing on the stage!”
142112.title: Tough it out!

1421121.content:
The two girls continued to playfully tease you about your inexplicable new talents throughout the rest of the morning. You put up with their attentions with good natured humor. Although in the back of your mind, you're still a bit worried where these strange theatrical quotations, newly found sense of rhythm, and sonorous soprano singing ability sprang from.

Still, after the recent breakup with your girlfriend, it's nice to have some attention from two attractive, available girls – even if the attention you're receiving comes in the form of friendly teasing over your strange, gender-bending vocal abilities.

“Harry, you want to come with us for lunch?” asks Melanie, glancing up at the clock. “Susan and I just pop around the corner to that little restaurant down the block each day. You should come with us!”

“Yeah, come on and join us, Harry!” says Susan, putting on her coat and grabbing her purse. “You always eat lunch alone and look so sad and dreary. Come out with us for a change.”

Again, it's nice to have the friendly attentions of two pretty girls, so you find yourself obliging them and heading off down the street to the corner restaurant.

“I'll bet Harry orders a light salad and a diet soda!” giggles Melanie.

“Ha ha,” you reply ironically. Inwardly, you're relieved though that your appetite hasn't been changed into sometime more delicate and feminine though. You order a big, greasy cheeseburger with extra bacon.

“Harry, you know I wasn't just joking before,” Susan says as the three of you dig into your food. “My cousin works at a gay bar – it's a really trendy, hot, upscale place. Anyhow, they do drag shows there all the time. I could get you an audition, if you're willing to strut your stuff up there on stage?”

“I told you, no!” you say in between bites of your hamburger.

“Just do an audition,” persists Susan. “You don't have to wear a dress for that. Just come with me after work. Melanie, you come too. We'll all go down there together. You just sing a little bit for them, and then hear what they offer you. It might surprise you to learn how much money a good female impersonator can earn.”

“I'm not a female impersonator,” you laugh. “I just a freakish talent for singing like a girl. A skill which, I might add, remained completely undiscovered to even myself until this morning. I have no interest in wearing a dress and wig. And even though I can contort my voice into sounding like a woman, my body doesn't look remotely passable for a female. I'd make a lousy female impersonator.”

“Susan and I would help you,” said Melanie.

“The point is moot, because I'm not interested in even trying,” you say.

So several hours later, why is it you find yourself walking into a place called The Polo Club with Susan and Melanie on either side of you?

“This is my friend Harold Finnegan,” Susan says, introducing you to a thin, pale man with dark hair. “Harry, this is my cousin Brian. I already texted him about your singing ability. Is there a place we can go to … like … audition, I guess?”

Brian laughed and shook your hand.

“Don't mind Susie,” he tells you. “She thinks that because our moms are sisters that she knows everything I do about showbiz. It's nice to meet you Harold. If you want to go up on that stage tonight, I'm happy to give you a chance. Whether or not you get a return invitation to go back up tomorrow, well that part is up to you.”

“I'm really not into all this,” you protest.

“Sing for him!” says Susan, kicking you in the shin.

You look around the club. They're open for business right now, but as most offices have only just closed for the day there isn't much traffic yet. A few solitary drinkers at the bar and a lone table with three men and a woman quietly nursing their drinks. Otherwise, there's just the bartender, Brian, and the three of you.

Drawing a deep breath, you resign yourself to the inevitable. As much as you're really uninterested in becoming a female impersonator at a drag club, you find yourself strangely enthralled by the prospect of singing again. It gives you so much joy and sense of purpose to belt out a song. You can't pass up the chance to sing again, even it means absurdly auditioning to be a female impersonator at a drag club.

“Ever wonder about what he’s doing, how it all turned to lies,” you start singing. “Sometimes I think that it’s better to never ask why. Where there is desire, there is gonna be a flame. Where there is a flame, someone’s bound to get burned. But just because it burns doesn’t mean you’re gonna die. You’ve gotta get up and try, try, try …”

The words are alien to you, but somehow they spring into your mind and slip out your lips without the slightest bit of conscious effort. You're singing right now, with the clear professional voice of a woman. The song is you, and you are this woman singing. Right now, you just let yourself fall naturally into the music and it takes away to a place where you aren't a measly little computer tech – you're a diva in the limelight.

You finish the tune, and the entire club sits still with stunned silence for a moment before suddenly bursting into applause.

“Bravo,” says Brian quietly. “That stage is yours tonight, if you want to work it? We can fit you with a wig and a pair of falsies, and Susan already mentioned she's got some clothes you could borrow. She and Mel seem quite overzealous about wanting to do your makeup, though if you'd like I've got a guy who'll do it professional for you. No offense sweeties, but stage makeup is different from what you gals wear at the office.”

“Whoa, whoa, whoa!” you say. “Look, I'll admit that I really get a kick out of singing. But I'm not gay, I'm not a cross-dresser, and I seriously have zero interest in doing a drag act here on stage tonight.”

“I think you're good,” Brian says softly. “I'll pay you a hundred-fifty for tonight, plus free drinks. Let me see you en femme, and we'll work out a deal for regular appearances.”

“What? You're crazy. You're all of you crazy!” you laugh. “This has to be a joke.”

Susan, Melanie, and Brian all look at you with expectant and utterly serious expressions.

“This isn't a joke, is it?” you ask.

Susan smiles and shakes her head.
1421121.title: Lunch with the girls

14211211.content:
"I'm not gay," you protest as Melanie and Susan drag you out of the club.

"Harry, please be don't be so naive. You don't have to be gay to perform at a gay club," says Susan. "It's camp! Theater. Showbiz. You've got an incredible female singing voice. Combine that with the image of you in a dress and wig, and it's pure entertainment."

"I still feel conflicted about all this," you admit. "There's something troubling about what's been happening to me today. I never even knew I could sing like this before this morning. Now, less than 24 hours later I'm talking about wearing a dress and performing at a gay club? It's nuts!"

"You said you enjoy singing," pointed out Melanie.

"True," you confess. "I get this weird buzz – a thrilling sense of elation when I'm singing ..."

... or, you silently add, when you're dancing or quoting obscure lines from plays only a true-blooded thespian would know. Just what is happening to you these days?

"Harry, we're going to have a blast," says Susan. "Now stop whining and pouting about something you just admitted you enjoy doing. If you like singing, then why fight it?"

The three of you caught a taxi back to Susan's place. Before you left the club, Brian had loaned you a professional theatrical wig and a pair of false breasts. They sat in two large boxes on your lap during the trip. The weight of the foreign items seemed to solidify the reality of your unearthly situation. You were really going to wear these things tonight and sing in front of people?

The thought terrified you ... and yet, you had to admit, it also sent ripples of enthusiastic delight throughout you. The girls were right: you really did want to do this.

And that fact alone scared you more than anything else.

At Susan's place, you open the boxes Brian gave you and look quizzically at these alien accoutrements of false femininity. You've worn a grand total of one wig in your entire life up to this point, and it was a silly hairpiece for a werewolf costume you wore for Halloween once as a kid. Now this strange, silky soft mane of blond curls sitting in the box was going to be attached to your head for the night? It was a beautiful wig, delicate and feminine. And just like your hauntingly alluring voice, these golden tresses would soon be jarring juxtaposed with the crude, hairy lump of blocky muscle that was your normal, masculine body.

How strangely fascinating, the contrast of these disparate, polar qualities – man and woman, all rolled into one.

All rolled into you!

"It's Marilyn Monroe," says Melanie. "That wig Brian gave you: it's a Marilyn Monroe wig. Can you sing like her?"

"I don't know anything about her," you shrug.

"I've got a dress I wore for a costume once," says Susan. "I went as Marilyn Monroe. It's going to be tight, but with that wig you'll be riot!"

You squint and frown, imagining yourself squeezed into one of Susan's tight, little dresses. Ridiculous!

As if reading your thoughts, she answers: "It's camp, Harry! You're just supposed to look entertaining. Nobody expects you to actually become the spitting image of Marilyn Monroe. Don't take everything so seriously."

"We'll have to shave his legs," Melanie adds soberly.

"And armpits," Susan says somberly.

"You just said it's not so serious!" you wail.

"Grow up, Harry!" laughs Susan, dragging you into her bathroom. "Let's have some fun with it."

The girls have you strip you down to your boxer shorts, and then set to work shaving your body with an electric razor.

"You want to do your bikini region yourself?" grins Susan, eying your crotch.

"No!" you snap, blushing.

"He doesn't have to shave everything," giggles Melanie. "I think he's passable now, in a dress. It's a long dress, right?"

"Here, let me show you," says Susan running off to the next room and returning with the garment in question: a strapless, floor length satin dress in shocking pink with a big cheerful looking bow in back.

"This is the sort of thing she wore in ..."

"Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," you answer correctly, without ever having watched a Marilyn Monroe movie before in your life. But just as the strange Shakespeare quotes kept flitting into your mind throughout the day, this new bit of film trivia somehow wormed its way into your memories as well. It's as though you've not only gained the ability to sing as a woman, but also gained the knowledge of stage and film trivia that a real life professional actress/singer might possess.

"I've got the gloves, diamond earrings, bracelets, and choker around here somewhere too," Susan calls out, digging through old boxes of stuff in her bedroom closet. "The earrings are even clip-on, Harry. So unfortunately, we don't have to get your ears pierced!"

Moments later, you find yourself wearing one of Susan's bras fitted out with big, bulging falsies, then the pink dress, the blond wig, the matching pink elbow-length gloves, and finally the faux diamond bracelets and necklace and earrings. Then you strike a pose in front of the bathroom mirror ... and grimace in disgust.

"I look like a drag queen!" you moan.

"You're supposed to," laughs Susan. "It's camp, silly! Now, there's no way my shoes are going to fit you, so just wear your regular ones until we get back to the club. Brian will have some heels in men's sizes for you to borrow I'm sure."

"You want us to do your makeup?" Melanie asks you. "Or do you want Brian's people to handle that?"

"We're running late already," answers Susan. "Plus, Brian was right: stage make-up is different from what we were Mel. Harry will be better off letting Brian's guy do that."

You gulp nervously at the reminder that you're going up on stage like this: as a grotesque she-male parody of a pop culture icon of femininity. How did you ever get talked into this?

The taxi ride back to the club is surprisingly low key. The driver makes no comment about your odd appearance in this tight, pink, formal dress. You figure cab drivers must see everything, over the course of a career ferrying weirdos like yourself around. It must take something truly bizarre to rattle one of these unflappable chauffeurs of the city.

The three of you arrive back at the club and receive an animated and eager welcome from Brian.

"You look smashing, love!" he says, clapping his hands together. "You need shoes though. I have just the right thing in pumps that hopefully are your size. Oh, and I'll send Kenny out. He's our make-up wizard. Once he's through with you, honey, your own mother wouldn't recognize you."

"That's what I'm hoping," you grumble while manually adjusting the heavy new false boobs jutting out from beneath your bold pink dress.

"If you're afraid to do this, then just don't," Brian says sagely. "Harry, I really think you've got that magic spark only true theatrical geniuses possess. You'll make a great drag queen. But don't go up onto that stage unless it's what you really want to do. If there are any reluctant, lingering doubts you have about this, then it's best you remain a face in the crowd instead of a queen under the spotlights."

"I really do enjoy singing," you confess to Brian. "But this is all happening so suddenly. I never even knew I could sing until this morning. Now, I get this amazing thrill when I'm singing. It's addictive, and I want more. I just don't know about wearing all this girly stuff and performing for a bunch of gay guys ..."

"Harry, you're looking at me, Susie, and Mel like you want us to give you permission to go on that stage tonight," Brian says gently. "We can't give you permission. You have to do that yourself. Do you want to sing or not?"

You sigh silently.

"Believe it or not, there's nothing gay about performing at a gay club," Brian continues. "This is the twenty-first century, hon – get over your homophobic hangups. Sexuality comes in all shapes and sizes. It isn't a rigid This or That, Black or White kind of deal. There's a whole rainbow, if you'll pardon the cliche: a spectrum that ranges from masculine to feminine, encompassing every delicious little quirk in between. We're all just people, looking for a good time. Now, you've got a gift of song to share. Does it matter what sort of costume you wear while you sing? Does it matter whether your audience is comprised of boys who like girls or boys who like boys?"

"I guess not," you reluctantly admit.

"So what's the big hang up?" smiles Brian. "This isn't about gay or straight, or whether you're wearing pants or a skirt. This is about singing, putting smiles on people's faces, making folks you've never met before happier than they were when they came into the joint. If that's good enough for you, then you're good enough for us."

"But if there's any hesitation," continues Brian. "If you've still got some hang-ups or cold feet about our stage feeling less than warm and inviting to you, then don't go up there. You won't be true to yourself, and you won't be true to us. The audience will know. Look, Harry: I respect a hard-working janitor who's passionate about cleaning a hell of a lot more than I respect a lazy stock broker who doesn't really care about his high-paying job. Anything you do, do it grand. Don't go out on that stage if you're going be scared, skittish and only do a half-assed job. Are you willing to try something new, Harry? It doesn't have to be perfect, but I don't want a lackluster, indifferent attitude. I want to see passionate effort, not reluctant cowardice. Can you shrug off those doubts and be enthusiastic about something you just said you really enjoy?"
14211211.title: Let the girls dress you in drag

choices: The clock strikes midnight while you are on-stage!
The next midnight transformation happens when you get just off-stage.
142112111.content:
The house lights went dark and the crowd began to quiet.

“If it be now, 'tis not to come,” you whisper to yourself backstage. “If it be not to come, it will be now.”

You smooth the satin fabric of your tightly fitting pink dress and gaze at the reflected brilliance of the sparkling fake diamonds adorning your gloved wrists.

The stage manager signaled you to wait for his cue. From outside, you could hear someone on the loudspeaker announcing the next act: “Lorelei Lee” … that was you, at least for tonight.

Butterflies flurried about your jittery insides.

“If it be not now, yet it will come: the readiness is all,” you whisper, the unfamiliar words providing strange comfort to your quivering nerves. “Since no man, of aught he leaves, know what is't to leave betimes, let be.”

Your churning insides become still and calm. You draw a slow, measured breath, channeling the shapely polish and poise of Norma Jeane, AKA Marilyn Monroe, at the height of her fame and success.

The stage manager signaled you, and with another deep breath of reassurance, you stepped out into the blinding, white hot beam of light streaming down out of the Stygian blackness of the club's ceiling. With feminine grace and elegance, you move fluidly across the stage in the two inch heels now on your feet, the long pink evening gown flowing along about your legs. The music begins faintly, and you start to sing.

“The French are glad to die for love. They delight in fighting duels,” you sing flawlessly. “But I prefer a man who lives … and gives expensive jewels!”

The music flares to full strength, and you find yourself nimbly frolicking and cavorting about the stage, strutting along with spirited poise and spunky confidence as you belt out Marilyn Monroe's most famous song with consummate perfection.

You may look like a man in a dress and a wig, but your vocals are spotlessly superlative and your enthusiasm is infectious. You've quickly got the crowd rapt attention focused purely on you and nothing else.

“I've heard of affairs that are strictly platonic – but diamonds are a girl's best friend!” you continue to sing. The smoky air, the hot lights, the enraptured crowd … they all seem to melt away as your new theatrical skills take full possession and you become a drag queen prima donna, first lady of female impersonators, and celebrity of the moment. You're still you, only now you're so much more, using your powerful new artistic proficiencies to turn on all the acting, the charm, the singing, and the grace of Marilyn Monroe.

“But stiff back or stiff knees,” you continue to sing. “You stand straight at … Tiffany's! Diamonds … Diamonds … no, I don't mean rhinestones, but diamonds are a girl's best friend!”

And the crowd erupts in applause, the entire room rising to their feet with thunderous of approval and delight.

In that moment, you're more than a drag queen. You are a singer and actress extraordinaire.
142112111.title: Diamonds are Your Best Friends

1421121111.content:
The clock strikes midnight while you're standing there, on-stage at a gay club, dressed as Marilyn Monroe, and having just received a standing ovation for your incredible performance of “Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend.”

What kind of transformation happens to you this time?
1421121111.title: The Cinderella Syndrome

1421121112.content:
The crowd erupts with applause. Apparently your drag routine has proven to be a big success! Who'd have ever thought you'd one day enjoy success as a female impersonator?

Life is full of funny surprises, you think as you walk off-stage.

Susan and Melanie are waiting for you. Each of the girls gives you a tight congratulatory embrace.

“You did great, Harry!” says Susan.

“Congratulations!” adds Melanie.

“Thanks,” you say, blushing a bit. You're honestly surprised at yourself. Until this morning, you'd never had the slightest hint of any musical or theatrical talent.

“It's getting late,” you say, noticing a clock on the wall shows it's now 11:59 at night. “And we all have to be at work, tomorrow!”

“If only Mr. Hoskins could see you right now,” grinned Melanie.

“Yeah, I'm glad he can't!” you laugh.

Just then, the clock strikes midnight.

What kind of transformation happens to you this time?
